thread.title: Rainey Street keeps hopping as a hot spot in Austin — for now
thread.title_full: Rainey Street keeps hopping as a hot spot in Austin — for now - Chicago Tribune

author: William Hageman
title: Rainey Street keeps hopping as a hot spot in Austin — for now
text:
Sixth Street has long been Austin's nightlife hot spot, but in recent years it's been getting competition from a stretch of small homes converted to bars and restaurants.
Rainey Street, located downtown, has become a destination spot in the 10 years since a zoning change let restaurants and bars move in.
Historically a middle-class neighborhood, it's dotted with small houses where tradesmen and stonecutters lived in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Starting in the 1960s, the area began to decline. Then came the zoning change.
 "A lot of people went down there for the charm and ambience and set up shop in these houses," said Steve Sadowsky, Austin's historic preservation officer.
Today there are more than a dozen bars and restaurants and numerous food trucks in the two-block stretch. You can find American fare (Javelina), Indian (G'Raj Mahal), Mexican (El Naranjo); food trucks serve tapas, bacon, tacos, gyros, pizza and other delicacies; for bar-hopping, you have your choice of Icenhauer's, The Blackheart, The Drafting Room, Clive Bar, Bungalow and more. Most locations have indoor and outdoor seating, some offer live music, and many are dog-friendly.
The anchor is Banger's Sausage House & Beer Garden, with 30 house-made sausages on the menu and 104 craft beers on tap. It's the brainchild of Ben Siegel, a California native who came to Austin for college. He always wanted to open a restaurant/bar, and his life took a turn when he saw a sausage cart on Sixth Street. "The lines were so much longer at the food cart than the regular restaurants," he said. "So the idea entered my mind at that point."
Banger's seats about 350, beer-garden style. Siegel could legally add another 150 seats, but the problem would be feeding them. The kitchen was designed for a 150-200-seat restaurant; Banger's now serves around 6,000 customers a week.
But the Rainey Street buzz made the neighborhood hot, and developers are sniffing around. High-rise condos and a 300-room hotel are under construction.
"It's going to be very dense," Sadowsky said. "I've seen renderings of what people think it's going to look like in the future, and it's horrible. It's all high-rises."
Info: http://www.raineystbars.com
